snippet.textDisplay: As someone who has a fair bit of experience working with physically as well as mentally handicapped people including people on the autism spectrum, and as someone who has a BEd. in psychology, I gotta say, you did a fantastic job interviewing these lovely people, Anthony. I've got a feeling you may have experience talking to people on the spectrum, cause, as Richard implied, not a lot of people manage to stay THIS casual when talking to people with autism. In either case, major props to you.
snippet.textOriginal: As someone who has a fair bit of experience working with physically as well as mentally handicapped people including people on the autism spectrum, and as someone who has a BEd. in psychology, I gotta say, you did a fantastic job interviewing these lovely people, Anthony. I've got a feeling you may have experience talking to people on the spectrum, cause, as Richard implied, not a lot of people manage to stay THIS casual when talking to people with autism. In either case, major props to you.

snippet.textDisplay:
Thank you so much for this video and bringing attention to autism and asperger syndrome. I have 2 very close members of my family that have it. My family really took a while to tell me ir and then I understood a lot of their behaviors. This video was really insightful especially because is not just about facts but more about the people being interviewed. People need to realize that these differences are just that, differences, and it shouldn’t be cause of bullying and harassment.
thank you so much
snippet.textOriginal:
Thank you so much for this video and bringing attention to autism and asperger syndrome. I have 2 very close members of my family that have it. My family really took a while to tell me ir and then I understood a lot of their behaviors. This video was really insightful especially because is not just about facts but more about the people being interviewed. People need to realize that these differences are just that, differences, and it shouldn’t be cause of bullying and harassment.
thank you so much

snippet.textDisplay:
"I spent a day with people with (social) anxiety disorder"
Since you were talking about panic attacks and this is usually related, also you had been mentioning how you experience anxiety as well. Having an anxiety disorder however can be a pretty big struggle in life. I would attend this kind of interview myself if I could but I'd also be probably very scared and anxious about it since my case is pretty severe I think. Anyway, it would be very interesting but maybe the hardest part would be actually finding people willing to do it because this kind of setting is usually also very stressful to most of people with anxiety disorder.
snippet.textOriginal:
"I spent a day with people with (social) anxiety disorder" 
Since you were talking about panic attacks and this is usually related, also you had been mentioning how you experience anxiety as well. Having an anxiety disorder however can be a pretty big struggle in life. I would attend this kind of interview myself if I could but I'd also be probably very scared and anxious about it since my case is pretty severe I think. Anyway, it would be very interesting but maybe the hardest part would be actually finding people willing to do it because this kind of setting is usually also very stressful to most of people with anxiety disorder.

snippet.textDisplay: This video would be a lot more respectful if you didn't start off as if Autism was this strange thing and it being "cured" was in any way a "solution". You seem to have a good idea in listening and do care about learning, but the tone of the beginning sets off a lot of alarms for me as an Autistic person, and I know of others who would feel the same way. It makes us feel like a spectacle, too, when you start it all dramatic. You're coming from a place of misunderstanding, which is totally fine! Just. Treat this like you're talking to people more, and not like you're in a documentary.
snippet.textOriginal: This video would be a lot more respectful if you didn't start off as if Autism was this strange thing and it being "cured" was in any way a "solution". You seem to have a good idea in listening and do care about learning, but the tone of the beginning sets off a lot of alarms for me as an Autistic person, and I know of others who would feel the same way. It makes us feel like a spectacle, too, when you start it all dramatic. You're coming from a place of misunderstanding, which is totally fine! Just. Treat this like you're talking to people more, and not like you're in a documentary.

snippet.textDisplay: this is a wonderful video and i was showing this to my loved ones to help them understand further on Autism.im on the spectrum aswell and i grew up non verbal,i got bullied so much both by adults and kids and told i was too slow ,couldnt speak and would be put on timeout all the time in recess for not even knowing what i did or why. My parents werent the best with me and it always caused me to feel like i was such a failiure and iit persisted in highschool,my 'friends' were very ignorant on that and bullied me alot too and talked behind my back,i always felt like theres such a HUGE misunderstanding on autism. we think and function differently but it doesn't mean we're any less human beings. we are compassionate and intelligent.personally growing up i felt i was always stupid or and felt guilt for how i interacted with people feeling like i weirded people out or so on.but i learned its not my fault i have autism and nobody should feel like a burden,ever. again this means so much that you made this video <3
snippet.textOriginal: this is a wonderful video and i was showing this to my loved ones to help them understand further on Autism.im on the spectrum aswell and i grew up non verbal,i got bullied so much both by adults and kids and told i was too slow ,couldnt speak and would be put on timeout all the time in recess for not even knowing what i did or why. My parents werent the best with me and it always caused me to feel like i was such a failiure and iit persisted in highschool,my 'friends' were very ignorant on that and bullied me alot too and talked behind my back,i always felt like theres such a HUGE misunderstanding on autism. we think and function differently but it doesn't mean we're any less human beings. we are compassionate and intelligent.personally growing up i felt i was always stupid or and felt guilt for how i interacted with people feeling like i weirded people out or so on.but i learned its not my fault i have autism and nobody should feel like a burden,ever. again this means so much that you made this video <3

snippet.textDisplay: This warms my heart! I have worked with many autistic kids and they are some of the greatest people I have met. If you just watch them as they interact with the world you'd be amazed at how creative, intelligent, and inquisitive they are compared to neuro-typical children! They can be challenging at times but rarely do they behave out of malice. They are a blast to be around and an absolute joy to work with!
snippet.textOriginal: This warms my heart! I have worked with many autistic kids and they are some of the greatest people I have met. If you just watch them as they interact with the world you'd be amazed at how creative, intelligent, and inquisitive they are compared to neuro-typical children! They can be challenging at times but rarely do they behave out of malice. They are a blast to be around and an absolute joy to work with!

snippet.textDisplay: when jasmine was talking about being bullied , it reminded my of my younger brother who has autism. It breaks my heart bc our family bullied him without knowing before he was diagnosed for talking too fast and not articulating, or being called lazy when a task overwhelmed him. Hell, last year in middle school he was frequently called out and picked on daily from the temp special needs teacher to the point where he would come home crying. This year is his freshman an year of high school and its so hard for him to concentrate or get along with anyone, he goes to the nurses office daily to avoid class and is already talking about trying to drop out. after his therapist moved we have had such a hard time trying to help him through it all
snippet.textOriginal: when jasmine was talking about being bullied , it reminded my of my younger brother who has autism. Hell, last year in middle school he was frequently called out and picked on daily from the temp special needs teacher to the point where he would come home crying. snippet.textDisplay: Anthony!!! Thank you oh so very much for this video. I think you made the interviews very genuine and personable. I am a school bus assistant in Colorado. My job is to help care for kids that need a safe ride to and from school that have autism and disabilities. I literally cried watching this video. Not because it made me sad, but because it made my heart so full! When I was younger, I used to be afraid of people with autism and disabilities. I was afraid.... because I wasn’t aware of everyone else’s way of living. (No it’s not my parents fault! My mom always taught me to treat others how I wanted to be treated. I just didn’t know mentally I needed to do that too, at that age). I was never rude or a bully.... but I was uneducated. Unfortunately a lot of bullying at school, on social media, etc. comes from being uneducated about a certain topic. At that time, we didn’t know about the spectrum as much as we do now. And it makes me so proud that I am not afraid anymore because as I got older, I researched different things that I didn’t understand... and now I have a job helping those who just need a friend. Who want someone to share their day with. To smile and laugh with someone, since at times, I’m the only happy face they see. I am there when they Need Someone to talk to or play games with when everyone else squeezes them into this box and they feel down about how they are treated. Someone Who wants to learn new things. Someone who just wants to ride the bus safely and quietly. Someone Who wants to live a full happy life, just like the rest of us. Someone That doesn’t let anything, including their disability, stand in their way. When others look down upon them, I am there to stand for them and be a voice when they don’t always know how or can’t be their own voice. I love my job, I love spreading the awareness, and I love that everyone views the world in different ways and that I can take that into consideration when speaking to anyone now. I have asthma, which is very different from autism, but it is a disability I have. People I know and have known for years always seem to forget that I have asthma and I can’t always participate in the activities they do... so I can understand to a small degree of being put in that box of no one understanding me and my condition. It doesn’t define me! But it is a part of who I am, but it doesn’t make me any less of a person. I am not on the spectrum, but I understand it more thanks to my job, and having the ability to learn about it as well as connect to those who are looked at differently. I get it now. Now the world must know! Just treat others how YOU wanted to be treated. I truly appreciate you helping spread that awareness and thank you to your interviewers for coming to talk about the unique world they all live in💜💜💜😭😭🙏🏽🤟🏽 Rock on my dude! Keep doing great things!
snippet.textOriginal: Anthony!!! Thank you oh so very much for this video. I think you made the interviews very genuine and personable. I am a school bus assistant in Colorado. My job is to help care for kids that need a safe ride to and from school that have autism and disabilities. I literally cried watching this video. Not because it made me sad, but because it made my heart so full! When I was younger, I used to be afraid of people with autism and disabilities. I was afraid.... because I wasn’t aware of everyone else’s way of living. (No it’s not my parents fault! My mom always taught me to treat others how I wanted to be treated. I just didn’t know mentally I needed to do that too, at that age). I was never rude or a bully.... but I was uneducated. Unfortunately a lot of bullying at school, on social media, etc. comes from being uneducated about a certain topic. At that time, we didn’t know about the spectrum as much as we do now. And it makes me so proud that I am not afraid anymore because as I got older, I researched different things that I didn’t understand... and now I have a job helping those who just need a friend. Who want someone to share their day with. To smile and laugh with someone, since at times, I’m the only happy face they see. I am there when they Need Someone to talk to or play games with when everyone else squeezes them into this box and they feel down about how they are treated. Someone Who wants to learn new things. Someone who just wants to ride the bus safely and quietly. Someone Who wants to live a full happy life, just like the rest of us. Someone That doesn’t let anything, including their disability, stand in their way. When others look down upon them, I am there to stand for them and be a voice when they don’t always know how or can’t be their own voice. I love my job, I love spreading the awareness, and I love that everyone views the world in different ways and that I can take that into consideration when speaking to anyone now. I have asthma, which is very different from autism, but it is a disability I have. People I know and have known for years always seem to forget that I have asthma and I can’t always participate in the activities they do... so I can understand to a small degree of being put in that box of no one understanding me and my condition. It doesn’t define me! But it is a part of who I am, but it doesn’t make me any less of a person. I am not on the spectrum, but I understand it more thanks to my job, and having the ability to learn about it as well as connect to those who are looked at differently. I get it now. Now the world must know! Just treat others how YOU wanted to be treated. I truly appreciate you helping spread that awareness and thank you to your interviewers for coming to talk about the unique world they all live in💜💜💜😭😭🙏🏽🤟🏽 Rock on my dude! Keep doing great things!

snippet.textDisplay:
Hey all, I was diagnosed with ASD a few years ago and I am now 17.
I still haven't been able to get over the label, since all I have known was autism as a bad thing. Ever since my school was told about my diagnosis I have been treated differently, like everyone is walking on eggshells around me and I hate it. It doesn't make me any less than others who do not have autism. Yeah okay I suck at social stuff and absolutely die inside in literally any social situation but i am getting better. It doesn't come naturally to me but that doesn't mean I cannot learn. Autism is different for every person affected, and for me the worst parts are:
Sounds are LOUD.
Warm is HOT.
Cold is FREEZING.
Awful awful awful panic attacks, where I just shut down and it is basically like I am not a person anymore. My hearing is muffled but at the same time everything is so loud, my vision is blurry, I feel like i could faint at any moment and it just feels like the whole world is closing in on me.
I cannot function in a social situation much longer than 30 minutes before I shut down - this is literally any situation with one or more people that I am not super close with, like my amazing Mum :) I can't even stay with some of my family for over half an hour. Before my diagnosis this pissed my teachers off so much hah.
Also it made my social anxiety disorder (abbreviated to S.A.D - very ironic) ten times worse than the average person with the diagnosis (of s.a.d)
It's so hard to concentrate. I have a seriously hard time making friends and keeping friends. mainly because I just prefer my own company because it is safer and it won't make me have a panic attack (most of the time...)


Okay I'm bored but yeah that's most of it but yet there is still so much more to it. Autism sucks but it also has some good to it. It made me super artistic and musical, and though I am definitely not the best at it, it definitely gave me a true passion that hasn't disappeared at all. It also makes it so I know any friend that sticks around is a true friend.


Though, I actually haven't told any of my 'friends' (not that I have any good ones). It's a scary thing to say because of all the stigma and all the assumptions. I am no different than who I was before you knew about my ASD. Why does the label always change people's opinion of me?


Overall, I am the same as you, whoever it is reading this. Do not treat me any differently, because even though it takes me longer to process the general stuff in life, I learn and I get there. We are not different.
At this point I don't even expect people to understand - even I don't really. I think different, and that's okay. I am still a person. :)

snippet.textDisplay: Wow, we sure have come a long way! From "Vax don't cause autism!" to "It's better than polio!" Between those two positions was there no logical reasoning being applied to the subject, or are people's opinion on this strictly guided by hive-mind thought processes? If vax ARE leading to this huge uptick in autism, then we, as a society, have a responsibility to hold big pharma accountable and do the work to mitigate this issue. Instead, we've begun to romanticize autism and say "It's not that bad!" I can't believe I have to say this, but autism SUCKS and is debilitating. I am shocked to see how quickly such a large percentage of people can vehemently defend a MASSIVE money making machine like pharma, while it is actively making us sick. And it's the people they are getting sick that become nearly violent in defending them. It's insane.
snippet.textOriginal: Wow, we sure have come a long way! From "Vax don't cause autism!" to "It's better than polio!" Instead, we've begun to romanticize autism and say "It's not that bad!" I can't believe I have to say this, but autism SUCKS and is debilitating. I am shocked to see how quickly such a large percentage of people can vehemently defend a MASSIVE money making machine like pharma, while it is actively making us sick. And it's the people they are getting sick that become nearly violent in defending them. It's insane.

snippet.textDisplay:
I hate when neurotypicals think that having autism is somehow end of the world (like to the point where it would be more okay to have a serious (or even potentially fatal) illness than autism). As an autistic person, I find it an asset. It is a strength that also comes with its downsides and huge hurdles, but truly, in my experience autistic people can be the most loyal and brutally honest (and kindest) people you can find. I also don't personally consider it a mental disorder (or really a disorder, to me personally it's a personality trait) as it's a neurodevelopmental condition that just caused my brain to wired differently from the majority. I might suck at social interactions (and at recognizing sarcasm... which is fun as my sense of humour is VERY sarcastic) but on the upside I have my own "superpower" in the form of a good memory and some level of skill in music and a definite affinity for learning languages which has enabled me to become a polyglot.

Also, it has to be noted that I have high-functioning autism (well, AS, but I am on the high functioning end of the spectrum) so I speak only from my own experience that can be radically different from others. It's not been all fun and walk in the park for me, either, I have been severely bullied and psychologically abused for years in my childhood and as a teenager (partly because I was different even if my autism wasn't known at the time).

I also don't personally consider it a mental disorder (or really a disorder, to me personally it's a personality trait) as it's a neurodevelopmental condition that just caused my brain to wired differently from the majority. I might suck at social interactions (and at recognizing sarcasm... which is fun as my sense of humour is VERY sarcastic) but on the upside I have my own "superpower" in the form of a good memory and some level of skill in music and a definite affinity for learning languages which has enabled me to become a polyglot.

Also, it has to be noted that I have high-functioning autism (well, AS, but I am on the high functioning end of the spectrum) so I speak only from my own experience that can be radically different from others. It's not been all fun and walk in the park for me, either, I have been severely bullied and psychologically abused for years in my childhood and as a teenager (partly because I was different even if my autism wasn't known at the time).

snippet.textDisplay: As someone who does have autism, it always bothers me how a lot of people make it their identity now adays. (This is unrelated to the people in this video. Just sharing.) Like I was a mod for a synesthesia group but it was pretty small, so I joined a bigger group, and there was a lot of people talking about autism like it was who they were and they were discussing everything as if it related to their diagnosis. It felt like if they didn't bring up that they were autistic every few sentences to explain what they said, then they'd just explode. As if they can't just have a personality. Like I swear they couldn't talk about likes and dislikes without using comparisons and saying terminology like neurotypical to define people or characteristics. They say that it's better to diagnose someone young, but as someone who almost was and then got diagnosed near adulthood, I've seriously noticed how it changes a person when they get diagnosed so young, because they're getting told by professionals that their behaviour is the result of a disability and not just their personality. When I was getting tested, they literally tried to tell me that having interests is an autism thing.. They were like, oh you like something.. well autistic people tend to get obsessed with certain topics and talk about them a lot.. and I'm like "Ye, that's called having interests and hobbies". When they tried to tell me this stuff and diagnose me as a kid, I genuinely was so effected by them telling me that a disability made me this way, that I started to lean into it and I would speak and act different and be a lot more awkward. It was only when I distanced myself from that and accepted I'm just me that I went back to being myself. However, more and more people getting diagnosed young end up permanently in that position I was put in for a while. The second that diagnosis hits, anything that's just awkwardness or fear instead suddenly becomes part of your condition and you're less likely to work on yourself or try to work on your social skills because you tell people that the autism makes you this way.
snippet.textOriginal: As someone who does have autism, it always bothers me how a lot of people make it their identity now adays. (This is unrelated to the people in this video. Just sharing.) Like I was a mod for a synesthesia group but it was pretty small, so I joined a bigger group, and there was a lot of people talking about autism like it was who they were and they were discussing everything as if it related to their diagnosis. It felt like if they didn't bring up that they were autistic every few sentences to explain what they said, then they'd just explode. As if they can't just have a personality. Like I swear they couldn't talk about likes and dislikes without using comparisons and saying terminology like neurotypical to define people or characteristics. They say that it's better to diagnose someone young, but as someone who almost was and then got diagnosed near adulthood, I've seriously noticed how it changes a person when they get diagnosed so young, because they're getting told by professionals that their behaviour is the result of a disability and not just their personality. When I was getting tested, they literally tried to tell me that having interests is an autism thing.. They were like, oh you like something.. well autistic people tend to get obsessed with certain topics and talk about them a lot.. and I'm like "Ye, that's called having interests and hobbies". When they tried to tell me this stuff and diagnose me as a kid, I genuinely was so effected by them telling me that a disability made me this way, that I started to lean into it and I would speak and act different and be a lot more awkward. It was only when I distanced myself from that and accepted I'm just me that I went back to being myself. However, more and more people getting diagnosed young end up permanently in that position I was put in for a while. The second that diagnosis hits, anything that's just awkwardness or fear instead suddenly becomes part of your condition and you're less likely to work on yourself or try to work on your social skills because you tell people that the autism makes you this way.

snippet.textDisplay: This was a very very good video. I have 2 friends who have autism. Then one knows what he has, and deals with it. The other I CAN'T EVER TELL HIM WHAT SO EVER that he have autism, cause inside in his head.. He is just like everybody else. He know that he's a bit different (or a bit clever, or more stupid) than everybody else but to overcome the acceptance that he has autism, will never find place! It so amazing to see other people with it because me as their friend, has always learned from my own experience, be with them. I studied IT education with those 2 guys and it was a hell of fun! Damn I learned so much from them! They see everything different!

The other I CAN'T EVER TELL HIM WHAT SO EVER that he have autism, cause inside in his head.. He is just like everybody else. He know that he's a bit different (or a bit clever, or more stupid) than everybody else but to overcome the acceptance that he has autism, will never find place! It so amazing to see other people with it because me as their friend, has always learned from my own experience, be with them. I studied IT education with those 2 guys and it was a hell of fun! Damn I learned so much from them! They see everything different!

snippet.textOriginal: The lack of eye contact in this video is so relatable oh my god (hi I’m autistic)

snippet.textDisplay: I have two cousins with autism . The older one is 50+ now and his mother never let him leave the house or go to school. He is very intelligent and when you are talking you can't tell he has a problem communicating or anything like that. He just stays inside the house looking at the world through the window even now. His mother already passed away and he is living with his dad now but he is still scared of leaving. The second cousin is a kid 5 years old and my uncle and aunt found out when he was 3, he is getting psychological help and his parents are very present in his life. I was the one who noticed he was a bit different from other kids because he had a difficulty communicating and focusing on things. He didn't talk much till he was 4 but after he started going to his doctor he got a lot better and won't shut up. Is still new to me the way he interacts with people like sometimes talking very loudly and making noises but he is still a kid. Thank you for this video.
snippet.textOriginal: I have two cousins with autism . The older one is 50+ now and his mother never let him leave the house or go to school. He is very intelligent and when you are talking you can't tell he has a problem communicating or anything like that. He just stays inside the house looking at the world through the window even now. His mother already passed away and he is living with his dad now but he is still scared of leaving. The second cousin is a kid 5 years old and my uncle and aunt found out when he was 3, he is getting psychological help and his parents are very present in his life. I was the one who noticed he was a bit different from other kids because he had a difficulty communicating and focusing on things. He didn't talk much till he was 4 but after he started going to his doctor he got a lot better and won't shut up. Is still new to me the way he interacts with people like sometimes talking very loudly and making noises but he is still a kid. Thank you for this video.

snippet.textDisplay: I have known several autistic people and they are lights in my life I will always remember. My cousin has an autistic son and he is really involved in theater and is so fun to watch. He's come a LONG way, and grown so much. I'm so proud of him. His parents are so great, they don't baby him, and they teach him and allow him to explore, and understand him. They just raise him to grow into himself and don't make him feel different or bad. I think he teaches me so much about how I need to get to know myself as a human, and he is so lovely and fun to be around.
snippet.textOriginal: I have known several autistic people and they are lights in my life I will always remember. My cousin has an autistic son and he is really involved in theater and is so fun to watch. He's come a LONG way, and grown so much. I'm so proud of him. His parents are so great, they don't baby him, and they teach him and allow him to explore, and understand him. They just raise him to grow into himself and don't make him feel different or bad. I think he teaches me so much about how I need to get to know myself as a human, and he is so lovely and fun to be around.
